page.title: 08HISTORY OF THE PORT
page.content:
Dover is on the South East tip of Great Britain. It is near the continent and it gives protection to ships in the strait, because of the cleft in the hills.
Romans used Dover the evidence exists in the form of the "Pharos", or lighthouse, on the cliffs of the east side of the valley.
During the late Saxon period the River Dour became greatly silted and the shipyard, which was situated in the estuary, was transferred to a point below the Western cliffs. King Henry VIII was interested in improving the harbour and ordered that a pier be built. However, the pier caused frequent deposits of shingle across the entrance.
